docs.title: About Me
docs.text:
• Hello everyone, my name is Shadil A M
  • 4th-year Computer Science Engineering student at KTU University
  • GSoC 2025 Contributor with Zendalona
  • Worked on zMantra – a math learning game for visually impaired students
  • Project involved accessibility, research, and real users
  • Visited blind schools and worked closely with real users
  • Founder of CodeCompass – an open-source student platform

docs.title: Disclaimer
docs.text:
• This documentation is based on my personal GSoC experience
  • GSoC selection varies heavily by organization
  • There is no guaranteed formula, only strong patterns
  • Your journey may look different — and that is okay

docs.title: How to Prepare for GSoC Before Proposal Season
1️⃣ Start Early
docs.text:
• Begin contributing well before the proposal season.
  • Explore the organization’s code, issues, and community.
  • Early contributions make you visible to mentors.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Become a Known Contributor
docs.text:
• Participate in chats, discussions, and mailing lists.
  • Help other newcomers and answer questions if you can.
  • Your consistent presence builds trust.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Prioritize Meetings Over Chats
docs.text:
• Meetings with mentors are stronger signals than casual chats.
  • Schedule short calls or voice/video meetings to discuss ideas.
  • Mentors notice students who actively seek guidance.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Build Prototypes Early
docs.text:
• A working prototype or small demo is more persuasive than promises.
  • Share prototypes before the application deadline.
  • Mentors use this as proof that you can actually implement your project.

docs.title: 5️⃣ Gather Evidence, Not Just Confidence
docs.text:
• Accepted pull requests, small contributions, or test fixes count more than self-confidence.
  • Show clear proof that you can finish tasks reliably.

docs.title: 6️⃣ Contact Previous Contributors
docs.text:
• Reach out to past GSoC students for tips and guidance.
  • They can help you understand the project better and avoid common mistakes.

docs.title: 7️⃣ Be Consistent and Communicate Clearly
docs.text:
• Contribute regularly, not just in bursts.
  • Ask clear, specific questions.
  • Update mentors on progress and issues.

docs.title: What is .git? (Super simple)
docs.text:
Think of your project folder like a school notebook.

  • Your code files = the pages
  • .git = a hidden history book

📘 .git stores:

  • every change you ever made
  • who made it
  • when it was made
  • how to go back in time if something breaks

👉 If you delete .git, Git forgets everything. 👉 If .git exists, the folder is a Git repository.

You normally never touch .git manually. Git commands use it for you.

docs.title: What is Git? (One sentence)
docs.text: Git is a tool that tracks changes in code and helps many people work together safely.

docs.title: Why big open-source projects use Git
docs.text:
Big projects have:

  • thousands of contributors
  • people in different countries
  • code changing every minute

Git helps them:

  • avoid overwriting each other’s work
  • review code before merging
  • roll back mistakes instantly

docs.title: The ONLY Git You Need to Know (for big open source)
docs.text: We’ll cover exactly what matters, nothing extra.

docs.title: Clone (most common for open source)
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/org/project.git

📥 This:

  • downloads the project
  • creates a .git folder
  • connects your copy to the original project

docs.title: 2️⃣ Check project status (MOST USED COMMAND)
docs.text:
git status

This tells you:

  • what files you changed
  • what is ready to save
  • what is not saved yet

🧠 Use this all the time.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Save your work (Commit)
docs.text: Git saves work in 2 steps.

docs.title: Step 1: Select files
docs.text:
git add file.js

or everything:

git add .

docs.title: Step 2: Save with a message
docs.text:
git commit -m "Fix login bug"

📦 A commit is:

  • a snapshot of your code
  • with a message explaining why

Big projects care a LOT about good commit messages.

docs.title: 4️⃣ See history
docs.text:
git log

Shows:

  • previous commits
  • who made them
  • commit messages

Tip:

git log --oneline

docs.title: 5️⃣ Branches (VERY IMPORTANT)
docs.text:
A branch = a safe copy of the code to work on.

Big rule: ❌ Never work directly on main / master

docs.title: Create a branch
docs.text:
git checkout -b fix-login-bug

Now you can:

  • break things
  • experiment
  • work safely

docs.title: 6️⃣ Switch branches
docs.text:
git checkout main

or newer Git:

git switch main

docs.title: 7️⃣ Update your code (before working)
docs.text:
git pull

This:

  • gets the latest changes
  • prevents conflicts

⚠️ Always do this before coding.

docs.title: 8️⃣ Push your work
docs.text:
git push origin fix-login-bug

This:

  • uploads your branch to GitHub
  • makes it visible to maintainers

docs.title: 9️⃣ Pull Requests (How open source really works)
docs.text:
You never merge yourself in big projects.

Flow:

  1. Fork the repo (GitHub button)
  2. Create a branch
  3. Commit your changes
  4. Push your branch
  5. Open a Pull Request (PR)

A PR:

  • explains what you changed
  • lets maintainers review your code
  • triggers tests

docs.title: Undo unstaged changes
docs.text: git checkout -- file.js

docs.title: Undo last commit (keep code)
docs.text: git reset --soft HEAD~1

docs.title: Undo last commit (delete code)
docs.text:
git reset --hard HEAD~1

⚠️ Be careful with --hard.

docs.title: 1️⃣1️⃣ Resolve conflicts (will happen)
docs.text:
Conflict = Git doesn’t know which change to keep.

Steps:

  1. Open the file
  2. Look for:
<<<<<<<
=======
>>>>>>>
  1. Fix it manually
  2. Save file
  3. Run:
git add .
git commit

Everyone hits conflicts. Even seniors.

docs.title: 1️⃣2️⃣ Big open-source rules (VERY IMPORTANT)
docs.text: ✔ Always read CONTRIBUTING.md ✔ Follow code style ✔ Small PRs > big PRs ✔ Clear commit messages ✔ Be polite in reviews

docs.title: Example: Real open-source workflow
docs.text:
git clone repo
git checkout -b fix-typo
# make changes
git add .
git commit -m "Fix typo in README"
git push origin fix-typo
# open PR on GitHub

That’s it.

docs.title: GitHub Terms & Features (Big Open Source Survival Guide)
1️⃣ Repository (Repo)
docs.text:
A repository is the project.

It contains:

  • code
  • issues
  • pull requests
  • documentation
  • history

📦 Think: one repo = one project

docs.title: 2️⃣ Fork (VERY IMPORTANT)
docs.text:
A fork is your own copy of someone else’s repo.

Why forks exist:

  • you don’t have permission to push to the main repo
  • you work safely in your own copy

Flow:

Original Repo → Fork → Your Changes → Pull Request

docs.title: 3️⃣ Clone
docs.text:
Download a repo (or your fork) to your computer.

git clone https://github.com/yourname/project.git

docs.title: 4️⃣ Upstream
docs.text:
Upstream = the original repo (not your fork)

Used to stay updated.

git remote add upstream https://github.com/org/project.git
git pull upstream main

docs.title: 5️⃣ Branch
docs.text:
A branch is a separate line of work.

Big projects require:

  • one branch per feature or fix
  • no direct commits to main

Example:

fix-login-bug
docs-update
feature-auth

docs.title: 6️⃣ Pull Request (PR) 🚀
docs.text:
A Pull Request is:

“Please review and merge my changes.”

PR includes:

  • code changes
  • explanation
  • discussion
  • tests results

Big open source lives on PRs.

docs.title: 7️⃣ Review
docs.text:
Maintainers or contributors:

  • read your code
  • leave comments
  • request changes
  • approve or reject

docs.title: Common review terms:
docs.text:
• LGTM → Looks Good To Me
  • Requested Changes → fix things
  • Approve → ready to merge

docs.title: 8️⃣ Merge
docs.text:
Merge = combine your PR into the main project.

Usually done by:

  • maintainers
  • bots (after approval)

You rarely merge your own PR in big projects.

docs.title: 9️⃣ Issue 🐞
docs.text:
An Issue is a tracked problem or task.

Used for:

  • bugs
  • feature requests
  • discussions
  • questions

docs.title: 🔟 Issue Labels
docs.text:
Labels help organize issues.

Common labels:

  • good first issue (beginner friendly)
  • help wanted
  • bug
  • enhancement
  • discussion
  • blocked

👉 Start with good first issue

docs.title: 1️⃣1️⃣ Issue Assignment
docs.text:
Someone is responsible for the issue.

  • Assigned → someone is working on it
  • Unassigned → available

Always comment before starting work:

“Can I work on this?”

docs.title: 1️⃣2️⃣ Milestone
docs.text:
A milestone = group of issues for a release.

Example:

v2.0
Bugfix Sprint
Security Patch

docs.title: 1️⃣3️⃣ README.md
docs.text:
The front page of the project.

Contains:

  • what the project does
  • how to run it
  • how to contribute

Always read this first.

docs.title: 1️⃣4️⃣ CONTRIBUTING.md (CRITICAL)
docs.text:
This file tells you:

  • how to submit PRs
  • naming rules
  • branch rules
  • commit message style
  • testing rules

❌ Ignoring this = PR rejected

docs.title: 1️⃣5️⃣ CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
docs.text:
Rules for behavior.

Used to:

  • prevent harassment
  • enforce respectful communication

Violations can get you banned.

docs.title: 1️⃣6️⃣ LICENSE 📜
docs.text:
Defines legal rights.

Common licenses:

  • MIT → very free
  • Apache 2.0 → free + patent protection
  • GPL → must share changes

Never ignore license rules.

docs.title: 1️⃣7️⃣ Discussions
docs.text:
Used for:

  • ideas
  • design talks
  • long conversations

Better than opening issues for questions.

docs.title: 1️⃣8️⃣ Projects (GitHub Projects)
docs.text:
A board to track work.

Columns:

  • To Do
  • In Progress
  • Review
  • Done

Used in large orgs.

docs.title: 1️⃣9️⃣ Actions (CI/CD) 🤖
docs.text:
GitHub Actions = automated checks.

They:

  • run tests
  • check formatting
  • block bad PRs

Your PR must pass Actions to merge.

docs.title: 2️⃣0️⃣ Checks
docs.text:
Checks show:

  • ✔ passed
  • ❌ failed
  • ⏳ running

Failing checks = no merge.

docs.title: 2️⃣1️⃣ Status Badges
docs.text:
Small icons in README:

  • build status
  • coverage
  • version

Shows project health.

docs.title: 2️⃣2️⃣ Commit
docs.text:
A saved change.

Good commit:

Fix crash on empty input

Bad commit:

fix
update
stuff

docs.title: 2️⃣3️⃣ Commit Squash
docs.text:
Multiple commits → one clean commit.

Used to:

  • clean history
  • simplify review

Often required before merge.

docs.title: 2️⃣4️⃣ Draft Pull Request
docs.text:
PR that is not ready.

Used when:

  • work in progress
  • want early feedback

docs.title: 2️⃣5️⃣ Templates
docs.text:
GitHub provides templates for:

  • issues
  • PRs

Forces contributors to include:

  • steps
  • expected behavior
  • screenshots

docs.title: 2️⃣6️⃣ Mentions (@username)
docs.text:
Notify people.

Examples:

@maintainer Can you review?
@team/frontend

docs.title: 2️⃣7️⃣ Notifications
docs.text:
You get notified when:

  • someone comments
  • review requested
  • PR updated

Big projects = lots of notifications.

docs.title: 2️⃣8️⃣ Security Advisories
docs.text:
Used for:

  • reporting vulnerabilities
  • private discussion
  • coordinated release

Never open public issues for security bugs.

docs.title: 2️⃣9️⃣ Releases
docs.text:
A release is a published version.

Includes:

  • version number (v1.2.0)
  • changelog
  • assets

docs.title: 3️⃣0️⃣ Tags
docs.text:
Tags mark important commits.

Example:

v1.0.0
v2.1.3

Used for releases.

docs.title: 3️⃣1️⃣ Watch / Star / Fork
docs.text:
• ⭐ Star → show appreciation
  • 👀 Watch → get updates
  • 🍴 Fork → contribute

Stars matter for project visibility.

docs.title: 3️⃣2️⃣ Insights
docs.text:
Stats about:

  • contributors
  • commits
  • activity
  • code frequency

Used by maintainers.

docs.title: 3️⃣3️⃣ Maintainer
docs.text:
A maintainer:

  • reviews PRs
  • merges code
  • sets direction

Be respectful. They’re often volunteers.

docs.title: 3️⃣4️⃣ Bot Accounts 🤖
docs.text:
Bots do:

  • auto-merge
  • auto-format
  • dependency updates

Examples:

  • Dependabot
  • Renovate

docs.title: 3️⃣5️⃣ Permissions
docs.text:
Access levels:

  • Read
  • Write
  • Maintain
  • Admin

Most contributors have Read only.

docs.title: What to Do After Choosing an Organization (Before Contributing)
1️⃣ Join the Organization’s Communication Channels
docs.text:
• Join their Discord, Slack, Matrix, or IRC
  • Subscribe to mailing lists
  • Follow GitHub Discussions and Issues

This is where real communication happens.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Read Documentation First (Very Important)
docs.text:
Before asking anything:

  • Read the README
  • Read CONTRIBUTING.md
  • Check setup guides and FAQs

Asking questions already answered in docs creates a bad first impression.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Observe Before Speaking
docs.text:
• Watch how maintainers communicate
  • See how issues and PRs are discussed
  • Understand the project’s tone and expectations

This helps you fit into the community smoothly.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Introduce Yourself Properly
docs.text:
When introductions are allowed:

  • your background
  • your skills
  • your interest in the project
  • your availability (especially for GSoC)

Keep it short and honest.

docs.title: 5️⃣ Engage in Discussions Thoughtfully
docs.text:
• Participate in GitHub Discussions
  • Join mailing list conversations
  • Ask specific, well-researched questions

Quality interaction matters more than quantity.

docs.title: 6️⃣ Help Other Newcomers
docs.text:
• Answer beginner questions if you know the answer
  • Share setup tips
  • Point people to documentation

This shows community mindset and leadership.

docs.title: 7️⃣ Attend Community Meetings (If Available)
docs.text:
• Join weekly or monthly calls
  • Listen even if you don’t speak much
  • Learn project direction and priorities

Mentors often notice regular attendees.

docs.title: Key Rule to Remember
docs.text: First become a community member. Contributions come after.

docs.title: What This Phase Builds
docs.text:
• trust
  • visibility
  • understanding
  • mentor recognition

All of these matter before your first PR.

docs.title: Steps After Choosing a Project
docs.text: Once you have selected a project, here’s what you should do next:

docs.title: 1️⃣ Communicate With the Organization
docs.text:
• Join the project’s Slack, Discord, mailing lists, or Matrix.
  • Introduce yourself briefly: who you are, your skills, and interest in the project.
  • Ask initial questions politely if something is unclear.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Understand the Project Deeply
docs.text:
• Read the README, CONTRIBUTING.md, and documentation.
  • Explore the codebase, issues, and past PRs.
  • Identify what the project does and what problems it is solving.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Make a Prototype or Draft
docs.text:
• Build a small demo or prototype related to your project idea.
  • It can be a minimal working version showing your approach.
  • Even a basic prototype shows mentors you understand the project.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Set Up a Meeting With Mentors
docs.text:
• Contact mentors after your prototype or early idea is ready.

  • Explain your plan clearly:

  • What problem you want to solve

  • How you plan to implement it
  • What your timeline looks like
  • Ask for feedback and suggestions.

docs.title: 5️⃣ Prepare for Contribution
docs.text:
• Pick small issues related to your project: bugs, documentation fixes, or setup improvements.
  • Start contributing before submitting your proposal to show trustworthiness.

docs.title: 6️⃣ Refine Your Proposal
docs.text:
• Incorporate mentor feedback into your formal GSoC proposal.
  • Link your prototype or early contributions in the proposal.
  • Make sure the plan is clear, feasible, and well-structured.

docs.title: Are You Good Enough for GSoC?
Short answer: Yes, if you meet the basics and put in effort.
docs.text: You do NOT need to be an expert.

docs.title: 1️⃣ You Do Not Need to Be an Expert
docs.text:
• GSoC is a learning program, not a senior engineer role
  • Mentors expect you to learn during the program
  • Many selected students start with limited experience

What matters more:

  • willingness to learn
  • consistency
  • communication

docs.title: 2️⃣ Basic Programming Knowledge Is Enough
docs.text:
You should be comfortable with:

  • one programming language
  • basic data structures
  • reading and understanding existing code

You don’t need:

  • advanced algorithms
  • deep system knowledge (unless the org requires it)

docs.title: 3️⃣ Git and GitHub Are Non-Negotiable
docs.text:
You must know:

  • cloning repositories
  • creating branches
  • making commits
  • opening pull requests
  • responding to reviews

This is essential for any open-source work.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Tech Stack Depends on the Organization
docs.text:
• Each organization uses different tools and languages
  • You don’t need to know everything in advance
  • You should be willing to learn what the org uses

Choose orgs where:

  • you know some of the stack
  • the rest is learnable

docs.title: 5️⃣ Many First-Time Contributors Get Selected Every Year
docs.text:
• You do not need prior GSoC experience
  • New contributors are selected every year
  • Mentors value fresh but reliable contributors

What they look for:

  • effort
  • learning ability
  • proof you can finish work

docs.title: The Real Question Mentors Ask
docs.text:
“Is this person reliable and capable of completing the project?”

Not:

  • “Are they the smartest?”
  • “Do they know everything already?”

docs.title: Final Truth
docs.text:
GSoC is not about being perfect. It’s about being:

  • prepared
  • consistent
  • communicative
  • willing to learn

If you have basic skills and real effort, you are good enough.

docs.title: Choosing an Organization
docs.text:
Before org announcement — how to choose an organization, and ONLY the choosing factors.

No timeline, no process, no extra GSoC details.

docs.title: Choosing a GSoC Organization Before Org Announcement
(Only the Choosing Factors)
docs.text: Before organizations are officially announced, you are not selecting a confirmed GSoC org. You are selecting a potential open-source organization that is likely to participate and right for you.

docs.title: The Only Factors You Should Use to Choose an Org
1️⃣ Your Genuine Interest (Non-Negotiable)
docs.text:
Ask:

  • Do I actually like what this project does?
  • Would I work on this even without GSoC?

Why this matters:

  • GSoC lasts months
  • mentors notice fake interest very quickly

If the answer is no → don’t choose it.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Technology Match (Reality, Not Dreams)
docs.text:
Choose an org where:

  • you already know some of the stack
  • you can learn the rest in 2–3 months

Avoid choosing based on:

  • hype
  • “this will look good on resume”
  • “everyone applies here”

docs.title: 3️⃣ Project Activity Level
docs.text:
Check:

  • commits in last 1–2 weeks
  • issues being answered
  • PRs being merged

Active project = alive mentors = real guidance.

Inactive project = high risk.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Contribution Friendliness
docs.text:
Look for:

  • CONTRIBUTING.md
  • setup instructions
  • beginner issues
  • welcoming tone in discussions

If onboarding is painful, selection will be painful.

docs.title: 5️⃣ Mentorship Signals
docs.text:
Good signs:

  • maintainers reply to questions
  • community chats exist (Slack/Discord)
  • previous contributors still active

You are choosing mentors, not just code.

docs.title: 6️⃣ Past GSoC Participation (Strong Signal)
docs.text:
Prefer orgs that:

  • participated in GSoC before
  • have public blogs or reports
  • accepted multiple contributors

Not mandatory, but much safer.

docs.title: 7️⃣ Problem Space, Not Just Features
docs.text:
Choose orgs where:

  • problems are clear
  • work can be broken into milestones
  • progress can be measured

Avoid orgs where work is:

  • vague
  • “research-only”
  • poorly defined

docs.title: 8️⃣ Size & Competition Level
docs.text:
Bigger orgs:

  • more slots
  • more competition

Smaller orgs:

  • fewer slots
  • higher visibility

Choose where you can stand out, not where everyone applies.

docs.title: 9️⃣ Long-Term Value (Beyond GSoC)
docs.text:
Ask:

  • Can I keep contributing after GSoC?
  • Would this help my career path?

Best orgs:

  • benefit you even if you don’t get selected

docs.title: Factors You Should NOT Use
docs.text: ❌ Stipend ❌ Org popularity ❌ Brand name ❌ “This is trending” ❌ How easy it looks

docs.title: Understanding Projects in GSoC (After Organization Announcement)
1️⃣ What a GSoC Project Actually Is
docs.text:
A project is:

  • A specific task or feature the organization wants to implement or improve.
  • Something that can be finished in the GSoC coding period (usually 12–14 weeks).
  • Usually part of an existing open-source software.

Examples:

Organization Project Example Mozilla Add a new feature to Firefox DevTools Django Improve the admin interface TensorFlow Build a demo or optimization for ML models Linux Fix a specific driver bug or improve a utility

A project is not the whole software — it’s a focused piece you can realistically complete.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Where to See Project Ideas
docs.text: After orgs are announced (usually February):

docs.title: a) Organization Website
docs.text:
• Most orgs list “GSoC project ideas”.
  • Example sections: “Ideas for Students”, “GSoC 2026 ideas”, or “Contribute”.

docs.title: b) GitHub Repositories
docs.text:
• Check the org’s repositories.

  • Look for issues labeled:

  • good first issue

  • help wanted
  • GSoC idea
  • Read the issue description carefully; this can be your project.

docs.title: c) Previous GSoC Projects
docs.text:
• Look at past years’ GSoC projects for inspiration.
  • Often, you can extend or improve a previous project.

docs.title: d) Community Channels
docs.text:
• Discord, Slack, mailing lists, GitHub Discussions
  • Mentors sometimes hint at ideas not publicly listed yet.

docs.title: 3️⃣ How to Choose the Right Project
docs.text:
Ask yourself:

  1. Interest & Passion

  2. Will you enjoy working on this for 3+ months?

  3. Skill Match

  4. Do you know some of the technologies?

  5. Can you learn the rest in 2–3 months?

  6. Feasibility

  7. Is it realistic to finish in the coding period?

  8. Mentor Support

  9. Are there active mentors to guide you?

  10. Contribution Opportunity

  11. Can you start contributing before submitting your proposal?

Tip: Early contributions (bugs, docs, tests) related to the project make your proposal much stronger.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Optional: Proposing a New Project Idea
docs.text:
Some organizations allow students to propose their own idea, but only if:

  • It aligns with the organization’s goals.
  • It solves a real problem.
  • You can explain how you will implement it and why it matters.

How to do it:

  1. Contact the mentor or ask in the community.

  2. Draft a small plan:

  3. Problem you want to solve

  4. How it improves the project
  5. Rough steps for implementation

Mentors will evaluate whether your idea is realistic and useful.

docs.title: How to Contribute to a GSoC Organization (After Choosing One)
First: Understand This Clearly
docs.text:
❌ GSoC is not about the number of PRs ✅ GSoC is about useful, trusted contributions

5 bad PRs = zero value 2–3 good PRs = very strong signal

docs.title: What Counts as a “Good” Contribution?
docs.text:
A good contribution:

  • solves a real problem the org cares about
  • is reviewed and merged
  • follows project standards
  • shows understanding of the codebase

This is what mentors look for.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Start by Understanding the Project’s Problems
docs.text:
Before coding:

  • read open issues
  • read discussions
  • ask mentors:

“What problems need help right now?”

Best contributors solve pain points, not random tasks.

docs.title: Good issues for GSoC contributors:
docs.text:
• good first issue
  • help wanted
  • small bugs
  • documentation gaps
  • test failures
  • performance issues

Avoid initially:

  • huge refactors
  • core architecture changes
  • unclear tasks

docs.title: 3️⃣ Talk Before You Code
docs.text:
Before starting an issue:

  • comment on it
  • explain your approach briefly
  • ask if you can take it

This prevents:

  • duplicate work
  • wasted effort

Mentors appreciate this.

docs.title: What a strong PR looks like:
docs.text:
• focused on one problem
  • clean commits
  • follows style guide
  • includes tests (if required)
  • explains why, not just what

docs.title: 5️⃣ Handle Reviews Like a Pro
docs.text:
Reviews are normal.

Good behavior:

  • respond politely
  • fix issues quickly
  • ask clarifying questions
  • don’t argue emotionally

How you handle review matters as much as the code.

docs.title: Realistic truth:
docs.text:
• 2–3 strong PRs → good chance
  • 4–5 solid PRs → very strong
  • 10+ tiny PRs → suspicious / low value

Mentors prefer:

fewer, meaningful contributions

docs.title: 7️⃣ Non-Code Contributions Also Matter
docs.text:
These count if they are useful:

  • improving documentation
  • fixing build/setup issues
  • adding tests
  • helping users in discussions
  • reviewing PRs

Especially good early contributions.

docs.title: 8️⃣ Show Consistency (Not a One-Time Spike)
docs.text:
Better:

  • small contributions every week

Worse:

  • many PRs in one week, then silence

Consistency builds trust.

docs.title: 9️⃣ Solve Problems They Actually Face
docs.text:
Ask questions like:

  • “Is this issue blocking a release?”
  • “Is this something users complain about?”
  • “Can I improve this workflow?”

Solving real pain makes you memorable.

docs.title: 10️⃣ Connect Contributions to Your Proposal
docs.text:
Later, in your proposal:

  • reference your PRs
  • explain what you learned
  • show how your project builds on this work

This makes your proposal believable.

docs.title: How the Contribution Phase “Works” (Mentor View)
docs.text:
Mentors evaluate:

  • reliability
  • communication
  • learning speed
  • problem-solving
  • collaboration

Not just code.

docs.title: How Organizations Select Contributors
docs.text:
GSoC organizations need to choose students they can trust to finish a project. They cannot pick randomly — they have to justify their choices to Google, because hundreds of students apply for few slots.

Here’s what they evaluate:

docs.title: 1️⃣ Proof That You Can Finish the Project
docs.text:
• Mentors look for evidence that you can complete tasks.
  • This comes from small, real contributions like pull requests or bug fixes.
  • They ask themselves: “Has this person shown they can finish what they start?”

docs.title: 2️⃣ Accepted Pull Requests Matter
docs.text:
• Merged PRs show you can write real, usable code.
  • One meaningful PR is more valuable than many small cosmetic ones.

  • The type of PR depends on the org:

  • Some orgs value code contributions

  • Others also count documentation, tests, or setup improvements

docs.title: 3️⃣ Good Communication and Regular Meetings
docs.text:
• Mentors need to know you won’t disappear halfway.
  • Regular updates, clear questions, and attending meetings show reliability.
  • Silence or delayed responses can quickly reduce your chance of selection.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Clear and Feasible Proposals
docs.text:
• Proposals must be realistic and achievable in the coding period.
  • Mentors prefer proposals that connect to previous contributions.
  • A clear proposal shows planning and understanding of the project.

docs.title: How Selection REALLY Works (Mentor Perspective)
docs.text:
GSoC selection is progressive — it’s not just about the proposal. Mentors observe your behavior in the months before submission.

  • Chat / discussions → indicates interest
  • Meeting with mentors → shows you are serious
  • Prototype / small working solution → earns trust
  • Silence or inactivity → usually means rejection

Basically, mentors select students they already trust and have seen work reliably.

docs.title: Previous Contributions Depend on the Organization
docs.text:
• Different organizations value contributions differently:

  • Some want several small PRs

  • Some prefer one or two deep, meaningful contributions
  • Some accept non-code contributions like documentation, tests, or reviews
  • Always observe the organization’s norms before contributing.

docs.title: What Mentors Actually Look For
docs.text:
When deciding who to select, mentors ask themselves:

  1. Can this student finish the project?

  2. Have they shown reliability in prior contributions?

  3. Will they disappear midway?

  4. Do they communicate regularly?

  5. Do they communicate clearly?

  6. Can they explain problems, ask questions intelligently, and respond to feedback?

  7. Do we trust this person?

  8. Trust is built over time, through contributions, discussions, and prototypes.

docs.title: ✅ Key Insight
docs.text: Selection is not random. Mentors prefer students they already know, have seen contribute, and can rely on. Your PRs, communication, and early engagement are more important than the proposal alone.

docs.title: What Is Google Summer of Code (GSoC)?
docs.text:
Google Summer of Code (GSoC) is a global open-source mentorship program started by Google in 2005.

Its main goal is not money, not internships, and not certificates.

The real goal of GSoC is to: - Help open-source organizations - Train new contributors - Build long-term open-source developers

In simple words:

GSoC pays beginners to learn open source properly, under mentorship.

docs.title: Why Does GSoC Exist?
docs.text:
Before GSoC: - Open-source projects struggled to find new contributors - Beginners didn’t know how to start - Students had time but no guidance - Organizations lost contributors after short periods

Google created GSoC to solve this problem.

docs.title: GSoC exists to:
docs.text:
• Bring new contributors into open source
  • Provide structured mentorship
  • Reduce contributor drop-out
  • Support open-source sustainability

Google benefits because: - Open source powers Google’s infrastructure - Strong open source = strong internet ecosystem

docs.title: What GSoC Is (And What It Is NOT)
GSoC IS:
docs.text:
• A mentorship program
  • A learning experience
  • A real-world open-source project
  • A long-term contributor pipeline

docs.title: GSoC IS NOT:
docs.text:
• An internship replacement
  • A guaranteed job offer
  • Only about coding
  • A shortcut to success

docs.title: What Happens in GSoC?
docs.text:
• You work on a real open-source project
  • You are guided by experienced mentors
  • Your work is reviewed publicly
  • You communicate regularly with the community
  • You become a trusted contributor

docs.title: How Long Is GSoC?
docs.text:
GSoC duration depends on project size:

  • 12 weeks (short)
  • 22 weeks (long)

But in reality:

You start months before selection and often continue after completion.

docs.title: January – Organization Applications
docs.text:
• Open-source organizations apply to Google
  • Google reviews their history and mentor capacity

docs.title: February – Organizations Announced
docs.text:
• Accepted organizations are published
  • Each organization lists project ideas

docs.title: March – Community Interaction Period
docs.text:
• Contributors interact with organizations
  • Discussions, small contributions, and mentoring happen
  • This phase often decides selection

docs.title: April – Proposal Submission
docs.text:
• Contributors submit detailed project proposals
  • You can submit up to 3 proposals
  • Quality matters more than quantity

docs.title: May – Results & Community Bonding
docs.text:
• Accepted contributors are announced
  • Community bonding period starts
  • You finalize timelines and goals

docs.title: June to August – Coding Period
docs.text:
• Actual development begins
  • Weekly or bi-weekly mentor meetings
  • Regular progress reports

docs.title: November – Completion (Long Projects)
docs.text:
• Long-duration projects finish
  • Final evaluations completed

docs.title: Eligibility
docs.text:
To apply for GSoC, you must:

  • Be 18 years or older
  • Be a beginner in open source
  • Be legally allowed to work in your country
  • Not be previously accepted more than once (depends on rules)

GSoC is open to: - Students - Fresh graduates - Self-taught developers

docs.title: Stipend & Effort
docs.text:
Project Size Hours Stipend Small 90 $750 Medium 175 $1500 Large 350 $3000

Important: The listed hours are minimum estimates. Most contributors work significantly more.

docs.title: How Is the Payment Made?
docs.text:
• Payments are handled through Payoneer
  • You must create and verify a Payoneer account
  • Payments are split into phases:
  • After passing midterm
  • After passing final evaluation
  • Taxes depend on your country

docs.title: What Happens After Selection?
docs.text:
After selection, you:

  • Sign participation agreements
  • Set up communication channels
  • Finalize milestones
  • Begin community bonding
  • Start coding according to the plan

Selection is just the beginning, not the end.

docs.title: Evaluation and Feedback
docs.text: GSoC has two formal evaluations:

docs.title: Midterm Evaluation (45%)
docs.text:
• Are you making consistent progress?
  • Are milestones being met?
  • Are you communicating regularly?
  • Are mentors satisfied?

Failing midterm usually means program termination.

docs.title: Final Evaluation (55%)
docs.text:
• Did you complete the project goals?
  • Is the code merged or usable?
  • Is documentation complete?
  • Can the organization maintain your work?

Passing final means successful completion.

docs.title: What Evaluators Actually Care About
docs.text:
Evaluations are not about perfection.

Mentors evaluate: - Consistency - Communication - Effort - Reliability - Willingness to learn

Missing deadlines without communication is the biggest red flag.

docs.title: Common Reasons People Fail GSoC
docs.text:
• Disappearing for days or weeks
  • Poor communication
  • Over-promising in proposals
  • Not asking for help
  • Treating GSoC like a job instead of a learning program

docs.title: Life After GSoC
docs.text:
After GSoC: - Many contributors become long-term maintainers - Some get job offers - Some continue as volunteers - Some become mentors in future years

The real reward is:

Open-source credibility + experience + network

docs.title: What Is a GSoC Proposal?
docs.text:
A proposal is your formal application to work on a project for GSoC.

  • It explains what you want to do, how you will do it, and why you are capable.
  • Think of it as a project plan + proof of ability + roadmap.
  • Unlike pull requests, a proposal is evaluated for feasibility and trust, not just coding skill.

In short: a strong proposal can matter more than 5–10 PRs.

docs.title: Why Do We Write a Proposal?
docs.text:
1. Communicate your plan to mentors.
  2. Show feasibility—you know what can realistically be done in the coding period.
  3. Demonstrate trust—mentors see that you can organize and finish a project.
  4. Convince the committee why you should get a GSoC slot over hundreds of applicants.

docs.title: Where to Apply
docs.text:
• Applications are submitted on the GSoC portal: https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/
  • After organization announcement, you can submit proposals to the orgs you chose/forked.

docs.title: How Many Proposals Can You Submit?
docs.text:
• Up to 3 proposals per student.
  • Recommended: focus on 1–2 strong proposals, not 3 weak ones.
  • Quality > quantity.

docs.title: When Can You Edit Your Proposal?
docs.text:
• You can edit your proposal until the submission deadline (usually mid-April).
  • After the deadline, you cannot upload a new proposal—only minor corrections may be allowed for formatting.

Tip: Don’t wait until the last day—mentors may give feedback during the community bonding phase.

docs.title: Why do some organizations collect proposals early?
docs.text:
• They may ask for early drafts before the portal opens.

  • Purpose:

  • Mentor meetings to discuss feasibility

  • Early feedback to improve the proposal
  • Pre-selection discussions
  • Early submission shows seriousness and commitment.

docs.title: What a Good Proposal Should Contain
docs.text:
1. Title – short, clear, and specific
  2. Abstract / Summary – 2–3 sentences explaining what you will do
  3. Benefits to the community – why your project matters
  4. Deliverables / Milestones – divide the project into achievable steps
  5. Timeline – weekly or bi-weekly plan
  6. Technical details / approach – how you will implement it
  7. Qualifications / Experience – skills, PRs, previous contributions
  8. References / Links – prototype, demos, documentation

Optional: link to a working prototype or demo at the top. Mentors should understand your project within 30 seconds.

docs.title: Proposal Writing – Reality
docs.text:
• Follow the organization’s template strictly – they often reject proposals that ignore formatting.
  • Length: 6–8 pages (more is not better).
  • Prototype/Demo link: very helpful to show practical understanding.
  • Clarity matters more than fancy language.

Example: Instead of “I will improve the system”, write: “I will implement feature X by adding module Y, which will reduce setup time by Z%.”

docs.title: How Organizations Review Proposals
docs.text:
1. Committee of mentors reviews all submissions
  2. Internal discussion: mentors debate feasibility, student reliability, and prior contributions

  3. Selection criteria:

  4. Feasibility (can the project be completed?)

  5. Trust (can the student deliver?)
  6. Prior interaction (PRs, prototype, discussions)
  7. Direct communication helps – asking clarifying questions or discussing your idea can increase trust
  8. Demonstrated effort matters more than ideas alone – mentors prefer students who have already contributed or built a prototype.

Here is a clean, clear, and professional version of your last points, integrated smoothly with the proposal section. This is written so you can add it directly at the end of your guide.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Ask Mentors to Review Your Proposal
docs.text:
• If possible, share your draft with the project mentors.

  • Mentors know:

  • what the organization actually expects

  • what scope is realistic
  • what usually gets accepted or rejected
  • Even small feedback from a mentor can greatly improve your proposal.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Ask Previous GSoC Contributors for Review
docs.text:
• Reach out to past GSoC contributors from the same organization.

  • They have:

  • already gone through the selection process

  • experience with proposal evaluation
  • They often point out missing details or unrealistic timelines.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Review and Improve Your Proposal Regularly
docs.text:
• Don’t write your proposal once and submit it.

  • Revise it every week if possible:

  • clarify goals

  • refine milestones
  • simplify explanations
  • Each revision should make the proposal clearer and more realistic.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Always Base the Proposal on Real Contributions
docs.text:
• Proposals are strongest when based on:

  • accepted pull requests

  • real issues you worked on
  • prototypes you built
  • Reviewers trust proposals more when they see:

“This person already understands the project.”

docs.title: 5️⃣ Share Your Proposal Link Properly
docs.text:
• When sharing your proposal (for review or feedback):

  • provide a clean, readable link

  • include context (project name, org, status)
  • mention what kind of feedback you want

Example message:

“Hi, this is my draft GSoC proposal for . I’d appreciate feedback on scope, feasibility, and clarity.”

docs.title: What Is a GSoC Slot?
docs.text:
A slot is basically a position for a student in GSoC.

  • Each slot means one student can be accepted to work with that organization.
  • If an organization has 5 slots, they can accept 5 students.
  • Each slot corresponds to one approved project.

Think of it like tickets for a concert — only students with a “slot” can participate officially.

docs.title: How Many Slots Does an Organization Have?
docs.text:
• Google decides how many slots each organization gets every year.

  • The number varies depending on:

  • Past participation – if the org successfully mentored students before, it usually gets more slots.

  • Mentor availability – more active mentors = more slots.
  • Organization capacity – how many projects they can realistically support.

  • Project quality and size – big, complex projects may reduce slots.

  • Typical range: 2–20+ slots, but some large orgs can get more.

Example:

  • Mozilla Firefox: 15 slots
  • Django: 5 slots
  • Small org: 2 slots

docs.title: How Google Gives Slots to Organizations
docs.text:
1. Organizations apply in January

  2. They submit their history, number of mentors, project ideas, past performance.

  3. Google evaluates:

  4. Success of past students

  5. Number of mentors available
  6. Capacity to guide students

  7. Quality of proposed projects

  8. Slots are assigned

  9. Once announced in February, the organization knows how many students they can select.

Important: Organizations cannot exceed the slots given by Google. So even if 20 students want to work with an org with only 5 slots, only 5 can be selected.

docs.title: Why Slots Matter
docs.text:
• It determines how competitive an org is.
  • Few slots → more competition, harder to get in.
  • Many slots → slightly higher chances, but still depends on your contributions and proposal.

Tip: Don’t only look at slot numbers — small orgs with fewer slots can be easier if you contribute early and show trust.

docs.title: When Should You Start Preparing for GSoC 2026?
Minimum Start Time: February (After Organization Announcement)
docs.text:
If your only goal is GSoC 2026, then you must start at least in February, right after the organizations are announced.

Starting later than this greatly reduces your chances.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Everyone Who Knows the Program Starts Then
docs.text:
• People who understand GSoC well begin immediately after orgs are announced
  • Mentors expect new contributors from this time

docs.title: 2️⃣ Organizations Start Engaging Early
docs.text:
• Mentors begin:

  • assigning meetings

  • answering questions
  • noticing active contributors
  • Early contributors get more attention and guidance

docs.title: 3️⃣ You Need Time to Build Proof
docs.text:
Selection is based on evidence, not promises.

You need time to:

  • make real contributions
  • get PRs merged
  • show consistent activity
  • build trust with mentors

docs.title: 4️⃣ Building a Prototype Takes Time
docs.text:
Strong applicants usually show:

  • a small prototype
  • design documents
  • early implementation ideas

You cannot build this in a few weeks.

docs.title: 5️⃣ The Learning Curve Is Real
docs.text:
Open-source projects have:

  • large codebases
  • new tools
  • strict contribution rules

You need time to:

  • understand the project
  • make mistakes
  • improve your contributions

docs.title: ⭐ Start Before Organization Announcement (Best Case)
docs.text:
The best approach is to:

  • identify potential organizations months before February
  • start learning their tech stack
  • read their documentation
  • make small contributions early

When orgs are announced:

  • mentors already know you
  • you already understand the codebase
  • your proposal is much stronger

docs.title: Simple Rule to Remember
docs.text:
February is the minimum. Earlier is always better.

If you start:

  • Before February → very strong position
  • In February → real chance
  • In March → risky
  • In April → very unlikely

docs.title: Final Advice
docs.text:
If GSoC 2026 is your priority:

  • don’t wait for official announcements
  • pick a few orgs early
  • start contributing as soon as possible

GSoC rewards preparation, not last-minute effort.

docs.title: How to Contribute to Open Source
How to Start Contributing to Open Source (Step-by-Step Guide)
docs.text:
This section explains exactly how a beginner should approach open source, from the first visit to a project to making real contributions in large organizations.

You do not need prior open-source experience.

docs.title: Step 1: Choose the Right Project
docs.text: Before writing any code, choose the right organization and project.

docs.title: How to choose a project:
docs.text:
• Pick a project that matches your interest (web, backend, AI, systems, etc.)
  • Check if the repository is active (recent commits and issues)
  • Look for beginner-friendly labels like:
  • good-first-issue
  • beginner
  • help-wanted

Avoid projects that: - Have no recent activity - Do not respond to issues or PRs - Have no documentation

docs.title: Step 2: Join the Community (Very Important)
docs.text: Open source is community-first, code-second.

docs.title: Join Communication Channels
docs.text:
Most organizations communicate outside GitHub.

Common platforms: - Discord - Slack - Matrix - Mailing lists

You can find links in: - README.md - CONTRIBUTING.md - Project website

docs.title: What to do after joining:
docs.text:
• Observe conversations for a few days
  • Understand how people communicate
  • Note how maintainers respond

docs.title: Step 3: Introduce Yourself Properly
docs.text: A good introduction builds trust.

docs.title: Example Introduction Message:
docs.text:
Hello everyone 👋
My name is Shadil. I'm a Computer Science student interested in accessibility and open source.
I’ve been exploring this project and would love to start contributing.
Currently learning <tech stack>. Looking forward to learning and helping!

Good introductions are: - Short - Honest - Clear about interests - Respectful

docs.title: Step 4: Read Documentation Before Asking Questions
docs.text:
This is mandatory.

Read: - README.md - CONTRIBUTING.md - CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md - Project wiki (if available)

Why this matters: - Most beginner questions are already answered - Maintainers respect contributors who read docs - Saves everyone’s time

docs.title: Step 5: Understand GitHub Basics
docs.text: Before contributing, you must understand how GitHub works.

docs.title: What Is a GitHub Repository?
docs.text: A repository (repo) is: - A project’s complete codebase - Includes code, documentation, issues, and history

docs.title: What Is a GitHub Issue?
docs.text:
An issue is a task, bug report, feature request, or discussion.

Issues are used to: - Track bugs - Propose new features - Assign work - Discuss improvements

docs.title: Common Issue Labels:
docs.text:
• bug: Something is broken
  • feature: New functionality
  • documentation: Docs improvements
  • good-first-issue: Beginner-friendly
  • help-wanted: Maintainers want help

docs.title: Step 6: Find an Issue to Work On
How to find issues:
docs.text:
1. Go to the repository
  2. Click on the Issues tab
  3. Filter by labels like:
  4. good-first-issue
  5. beginner

docs.title: Before starting:
docs.text:
• Read the issue fully
  • Check comments
  • See if someone is already assigned

docs.title: Claiming an issue:
docs.text:
Comment politely: 

Hi, I’d like to work on this issue. May I take it?

````

Wait for confirmation before starting.

---

## Step 7: Fork the Repository (Beginner Explanation)

### What Is Forking?

Forking means:
- Creating **your own copy** of the project on your GitHub account
- You can safely experiment without affecting the original project

### How to Fork:
1. Open the repository
2. Click the **Fork** button (top-right)
3. GitHub creates a copy under your account

---

## Step 8: Clone the Repository Locally

Cloning means downloading the code to your computer.

### Steps:
1. Go to your forked repository
2. Click **Code → HTTPS**
3. Copy the URL
4. Run:
```bash
git clone <copied-url>
````

Now the project exists on your local machine.

---

## Step 9: Run the Project Locally

This step is **critical**.

### Why?

* If it doesn’t run, you can’t fix it
* Setup issues themselves are valid contributions

Follow instructions in:

* `README.md`
* Setup guides

If the project fails to run:

* Try to fix it
* If successful, document the fix
* This alone can be a great first PR

---

## Step 10: Create a New Branch

Never work on the `main` branch.

```bash
git checkout -b fix-issue-123

Branch names should describe the change.

docs.title: Step 11: Make Small, Meaningful Changes
docs.text:
Good first contributions:

  • Fix typos or broken links
  • Improve documentation
  • Fix simple bugs
  • Add tests
  • Improve error messages

Avoid:

  • Massive refactors
  • Changing unrelated files

docs.title: Step 12: Commit Your Changes
docs.text:
A commit saves your work.

git add .
git commit -m "Fix setup instructions for Linux"

Good commit messages:

  • Short
  • Descriptive
  • Professional

docs.title: Step 13: Push Changes to Your Fork
docs.text: git push origin fix-issue-123

docs.title: What Is a Pull Request?
docs.text:
A Pull Request:

  • Requests maintainers to review your changes
  • Proposes merging your code into the main project

docs.title: How to create a PR:
docs.text:
1. Go to your fork on GitHub
  2. Click Compare & Pull Request
  3. Fill in the template carefully

docs.title: Step 15: Write a Good Pull Request Description
docs.text:
Include:

  • What you changed
  • Why you changed it
  • Link the related issue (Fixes #123)

Example:

This PR fixes the setup issue on Linux by updating dependency instructions.
Fixes #123

docs.title: Step 16: Handle Review Feedback
docs.text:
This is normal and expected.

Maintainers may:

  • Ask for changes
  • Suggest improvements
  • Request clarification

How to respond:

  • Be polite
  • Ask questions if unclear
  • Push updates to the same PR

docs.title: Step 17: PR Gets Merged 🎉
docs.text:
Once approved:

  • Your code becomes part of the project
  • You are now an open-source contributor

This builds trust.

docs.title: Step 18: Be Consistent
docs.text:
Big organizations value:

  • Regular contributors
  • Good communication
  • Long-term involvement

After first PR:

  • Take another issue
  • Help others
  • Review PRs
  • Attend meetings

docs.title: What Is Open Source?
docs.text:
Open source means that the source code of a software is publicly available for anyone to see, use, modify, and improve.

Instead of being controlled by a single company or individual, open-source software is built by a community of developers from around the world.

Key ideas behind open source:

  • Source code is publicly accessible
  • Anyone can read, modify, and contribute
  • Development happens transparently
  • Learning happens in public
  • Open source is shared responsibility, not free labor

Open source is not just about code — it is about trust, collaboration, and long-term sustainability.

docs.title: Types of Open Source Software
docs.text: Not all open source is the same. Different licenses define how software can be used.

docs.title: 1. Permissive Open Source Licenses
docs.text:
These licenses are very flexible.

Examples: - MIT License - BSD License - Apache 2.0

What this means: - You can use the code in personal or commercial projects - You can modify it and even sell it - Very few restrictions

Most startups and companies prefer permissive licenses.

docs.title: 2. Copyleft (Restrictive) Open Source Licenses
docs.text:
These licenses protect openness.

Examples: - GPL (General Public License) - AGPL

What this means: - If you modify and distribute the software, your changes must also be open source - Prevents companies from taking community work and closing it

These licenses protect freedom but limit commercial use.

docs.title: 3. Open Core Model
docs.text:
A mix of open and closed source.

  • Core features are open source
  • Advanced or enterprise features are paid

Used by many companies to sustain open-source projects.

docs.title: Why Companies Use Open Source
docs.text: Companies do not use open source because it is free. They use it because it is better engineering.

docs.title: 1. Faster Development
docs.text:
• Companies do not reinvent the wheel
  • They build on tested, battle-proven software
  • Saves time and money

docs.title: 2. Higher Quality Software
docs.text:
• Thousands of developers review the code
  • Bugs are found and fixed faster
  • Security issues are caught early

docs.title: 3. Talent Attraction
docs.text:
• Developers trust open-source companies
  • Contributors become future employees
  • GitHub profile matters more than resumes

docs.title: 4. Innovation at Scale
docs.text:
• Open source allows global collaboration
  • Best ideas win, not company hierarchy
  • Rapid evolution of technology

Examples: - Google uses Linux everywhere - Microsoft maintains thousands of open-source projects - Meta, Amazon, Netflix depend on open source

docs.title: Why Open Source Matters to Software Developers
docs.text: Open source is career acceleration for developers.

docs.title: 1. Real-World Experience
docs.text:
• You work on production-grade code
  • You learn industry-level standards
  • You see how large systems are built

docs.title: 2. Learning Beyond Tutorials
docs.text:
• Tutorials show ideal cases
  • Open source shows real problems
  • You learn debugging, design trade-offs, and maintenance

docs.title: 3. Public Proof of Skill
docs.text:
• Your work is visible to everyone
  • Recruiters can see actual code, not claims
  • Your GitHub becomes your portfolio

docs.title: 4. Communication & Collaboration
docs.text:
• You learn to explain ideas clearly
  • You work with people across cultures
  • You learn how professional teams function

docs.title: How Open Source Is Important in a Developer’s Life
docs.text:
For a software developer, open source is:

  • A learning platform
  • A career launchpad
  • A networking tool
  • A confidence builder

It teaches: - How to read other people’s code - How to write maintainable software - How to handle feedback and criticism - How to work in long-term projects

Most developers learn more from one open-source project than from multiple courses.

docs.title: How Contributing to Open Source Helps in Real Life
1. Better Problem-Solving Skills
docs.text:
• You face unclear problems
  • You learn to research independently
  • You learn to ask the right questions

docs.title: 2. Professional Discipline
docs.text:
• Writing clean commits
  • Following project guidelines
  • Meeting deadlines
  • Maintaining consistency

These skills directly translate to real jobs.

docs.title: 3. Confidence Growth
docs.text:
• Your code is reviewed by experienced developers
  • You realize you are capable
  • Fear of “not good enough” slowly disappears

docs.title: 4. Strong Network
docs.text:
• Mentors remember contributors
  • Contributors recommend contributors
  • Opportunities come through people, not forms

docs.title: Common Myths About Open Source
docs.text:
Myth: You must be an expert Truth: Most contributors are learners

Myth: Only coding matters Truth: Documentation, testing, design, and communication matter equally

Myth: Open source is unpaid work Truth: Open source builds skills that lead to paid opportunities

docs.title: Open Source and Programs Like GSoC
docs.text:
Programs like Google Summer of Code exist to: - Support new contributors - Fund open-source development - Build long-term communities

GSoC is not the goal. Open source is the goal. GSoC is just one path.

docs.title: What Is an Open-Source Organization?
docs.text:
An open-source organization builds software where:

  • the code is public
  • anyone can read it
  • anyone can contribute

Examples:

  • Linux Foundation projects
  • Mozilla
  • Kubernetes
  • Django
  • Apache Software Foundation

📦 The code lives on platforms like GitHub.

docs.title: Why Do Open-Source Organizations Exist?
docs.text:
They exist to:

  • build shared technology
  • avoid reinventing the wheel
  • improve software faster through collaboration
  • keep important software free and transparent

Many things you use daily depend on open source:

  • Android
  • Chrome
  • servers
  • cloud tools
  • AI frameworks

docs.title: Why Do Open-Source Orgs Collaborate With GSoC?
Short answer:
docs.text: Talent + funding + sustainability

docs.title: 1️⃣ They Get New Contributors
docs.text:
GSoC brings:

  • motivated students
  • fresh energy
  • long-term contributors

Many GSoC students:

  • stay after the program
  • become maintainers later

docs.title: 2️⃣ Google Pays, Not the Org
docs.text:
Important:

  • Google pays the student stipend
  • Google does not pay the org
  • orgs volunteer mentors

So orgs get:

  • real development work
  • no financial cost

docs.title: 3️⃣ They Can Work on Hard but Important Tasks
docs.text:
Maintainers are busy.

GSoC lets them:

  • assign large tasks
  • improve documentation
  • refactor old code
  • build new features

docs.title: 4️⃣ Community Growth
docs.text:
Healthy open source needs:

  • many contributors
  • not just 1–2 maintainers

GSoC helps:

  • avoid burnout
  • spread knowledge

docs.title: How Do Open-Source Organizations Make Money?
docs.text: This is where most beginners get confused.

docs.title: ❗ Open source ≠ free labor
docs.text: There are many funding models.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Company-Backed Open Source
docs.text:
Big companies fund projects because they use them.

Examples:

  • Google → Kubernetes
  • Meta → React
  • Red Hat → Linux

💰 Money comes from:

  • company salaries
  • enterprise services
  • cloud products

Developers are full-time employees.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Foundations & Donations
docs.text:
Examples:

  • Apache Foundation
  • Mozilla Foundation

Funding comes from:

  • donations
  • sponsorships
  • grants

Money is used for:

  • infrastructure
  • events
  • paying maintainers (sometimes)

docs.title: 3️⃣ Open Core Model
docs.text:
• core software is free
  • advanced features are paid

Used by:

  • GitLab
  • Elastic (earlier model)

docs.title: 4️⃣ Support & Consulting
docs.text:
Organizations make money by:

  • selling support
  • training
  • enterprise help

Example:

  • “We help you run this open-source software at scale”

docs.title: 5️⃣ Grants & Programs (Like GSoC)
docs.text:
• Google funds contributors
  • orgs get development without paying salaries

docs.title: How Do Open-Source Developers Make a Living?
docs.text: This is the most important question.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Full-Time Job (Most Common)
docs.text:
Developers work on open source as their job.

They are paid by:

  • Google
  • Red Hat
  • Microsoft
  • startups

Their work just happens to be public.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Maintainers with Sponsorships
docs.text:
Some maintainers earn via:

  • GitHub Sponsors
  • donations
  • company sponsorships

This works mostly for:

  • popular projects
  • core infrastructure tools

docs.title: 3️⃣ Consulting & Freelancing
docs.text:
Developers:

  • become experts in a project
  • offer paid help to companies

docs.title: 4️⃣ Grants & Fellowships
docs.text:
Some foundations pay:

  • stipends
  • fellowships
  • research grants

docs.title: 5️⃣ Career Growth (Indirect Money)
docs.text:
Open source helps developers:

  • build reputation
  • get job offers
  • get interviews easily

Many people get hired because of GitHub.

docs.title: How GSoC Fits into All This
docs.text:
GSoC is:

  • not charity
  • not free labor
  • not an internship

It is:

  • Google investing in open source
  • orgs investing time
  • students investing effort

Everyone benefits.

docs.title: What Students Get from GSoC
docs.text:
• stipend
  • real-world experience
  • mentor guidance
  • strong resume
  • long-term career boost

docs.title: What Orgs Get
docs.text:
• contributors
  • features completed
  • future maintainers

docs.title: What Google Gets
docs.text:
• healthier open-source ecosystem
  • better infrastructure for the internet
  • trained developers
